text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Health &
Medicine Daily \-- Investigators publish new report on Health and Medicine -
Reproductive Medicine. According to news reporting originating from Auckland,
New Zealand, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "Adjuncts, more often
known as add-ons, are now part of the landscape of an in vitro fertilization
cycle. Since the early days of in vitro fertilization, fertility services have
rightly been seeking improved success rates."

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from the University of
Auckland, "At present there are a multitude of choices for patients who are
usually presented with a menu of add-ons to choose from. This is driven by the
desire to give patients the best chances of becoming parents. This Views and
Reviews series discusses all aspects of add-ons. It is not exhaustive as even
as we are finishing the preparation of the series, there is a new study about
the use of cytokines as an add-on."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The overall conclusion
from this series of articles is that despite considerable efforts to establish
benefits with add-ons that there is a paucity of data when we consider the
outcome of live birth."

For more information on this research see: Introduction: Add-ons for assisted
reproductive technology: can we be honest here? _Fertility and Sterility_ ,
2019;112(6):971-972. _Fertility and Sterility_ can be contacted at: Elsevier
Science Inc, 360 Park Ave South, New York, NY 10010-1710, USA. (Elsevier \-
[www.elsevier.com](http://www.elsevier.com); Fertility and Sterility -
<http://www.journals.elsevier.com/fertility-and-sterility/>)

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting C. Farquhar, Dept. of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, University of
Auckland and Fertility Plus, Auckland District Health Board, Auckland, New
Zealand.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fertnstert.2019.10.010>. This DOI is a link to an
online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be
your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the journal _Fertility and Sterility_ is:
Elsevier Science Inc, 360 Park Ave South, New York, NY 10010-1710, USA.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: New Findings from University of Auckland in the Area of Reproductive Medicine Reported (Introduction: Add-ons for assisted reproductive technology: can we be honest here?): Health and Medicine - Reproductive Medicine
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Health & Medicine Daily -- Investigators publish new report on Health and Medicine - Reproductive Medicine. According to news reporting originating from Auckland, New Zealand, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, “Adjuncts, more often known as add-ons, are now part of the landscape of an in vitro fertilization cycle. Since the early days of in vitro fertilization, fertility services have rightly been seeking improved success rates.”

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from the University of Auckland, “At present there are a multitude of choices for patients who are usually presented with a menu of add-ons to choose from. This is driven by the desire to give patients the best chances of becoming parents. This Views and Reviews series discusses all aspects of add-ons. It is not exhaustive as even as we are finishing the preparation of the series, there is a new study about the use of cytokines as an add-on.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “The overall conclusion from this series of articles is that despite considerable efforts to establish benefits with add-ons that there is a paucity of data when we consider the outcome of live birth.”

For more information on this research see: Introduction: Add-ons for assisted reproductive technology: can we be honest here? Fertility and Sterility, 2019;112(6):971-972. Fertility and Sterility can be contacted at: Elsevier Science Inc, 360 Park Ave South, New York, NY 10010-1710, USA. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Fertility and Sterility - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/fertility-and-sterility/)

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting C. Farquhar, Dept. of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, University of Auckland and Fertility Plus, Auckland District Health Board, Auckland, New Zealand.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fertnstert.2019.10.010. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the journal Fertility and Sterility is: Elsevier Science Inc, 360 Park Ave South, New York, NY 10010-1710, USA.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
